Single Dorm Room

Expected to work 20 hours per week, but its actually a full time job. That means if someone knocks at your door at 2am you have to answer it and take care of whatever is going on.
Also, if you do a Puke clean up you get an extra $25, but the university charges you for the cleaning product used so its only ~$18...
Management claims to be open and accepting of any differing opinions on issues, but if you have a different opinion on an issue, you dare not speak out.

pros: Excellent State of Wisconsin Benefits
cons: The overall atmosphere is negative due to declining enrollments and budget shortfalls.

review_title: Red tape, brick walls, and "alumni club" mentality
pros:
- UW-Platteville runs at a slower pace, so if you are looking for something different than corporate America this is it. 
- The state has some benefits that are mandatory to sign up for, but all in all a very good benefits package with medical, dental, vision, life, and good premiums
- Paid vacation and paid sick days
cons:
- Because this is an institution of higher education AND a state institution, innovation and thinking outside of the box does no good - there is red tape blocking everything you want to do to make your job more effective. 
- State restrictions means you can procure services and contracts from the lowest bidder, not the BEST bidder. 
- Death by a thousand committees definitely applies here
- There are definitely cliques or clubs, where individuals who are "academics" or  alumni act superior toward others. 
- There is no governance or accountability for management/senior administration...If you have a good manager you may be able to do your job and count your blessings, if you have a bad manager you will be blocked at every turn and feel completely ineffective.

pros: Great people to work with.
cons: The town is too small

pros:
This is my first time in a higher education position and the difference between this and the corporate environment is astonishing.  Within our department, the doors are always open, communication and ideas are continually encouraged and there is a great sense of work/life balance.  When an idea is expressed and agreed upon, we implement!  We confer with members of the UWP community to ensure an idea will work from all angles.  At the end of the day - we are all here for the students.

I have read in previous reviews that budget cuts were listed under Con.  This is understandable.  We are also a state government agency and those types of budget constraints are beyond our control.  The university makes up for it with incredible benefits and work/life balance.  People here do not work the 50-60+/hours per week that you may see in a corporate setting.  It is about quality, not quantity.
cons: Parking has been brought up as an issue.  I have been in meetings where the parking matter has been addressed and I know it is a topic of concern for administration.

pros: Great benefits (including health care & well-managed retirement), decent training, interesting co-workers, chance to interact with college students, and many opportunities to serve the public in a meaningful way.
cons: Pay for faculty is low compared to other comparable UW campuses (e.g., average pay for assistant professors is about 11k below UW-La Crosse).  There are exceptionally high expectations despite the low pay.  In some departments there is an unhealthy culture of working long hours.  It is not uncommon for faculty to spend 12 hours a day in the office and then come in on Saturdays.  However, the long hours don't equate productivity.  Bureaucracy is stifling.

pros: Lots of flexibility and encouragement to learn about other job roles and cross-train. Decent support for professional development. Encouraged to get involved with campus-wide committees. Benefits were fine, excellent PTO. Strong team-based atmosphere in my division.  This is an excellent campus to build experience and be able to move on to bigger and better things.
cons:
Poor pay, no raises beyond the state-mandated 2% in a couple of years so income didn't keep up with inflation/CoL. Lots of budget issues across the university and UW system. Gossip is a huge issue across the university and in the department because there is no transparency from administrators. 

Very little in the way of a career ladder/promotion opportunities.

pros:
Great chance for interactions with students. 

Faculty interactions vary by department. Some departments are so toxic that professional mediators are needed during routine meetings (I'm not joking), while other departments have regular get-togethers and everyone's good friends outside of work. Ask around before you accept a position. Be careful that hiring committees aren't entirely honest. They will say what they need to in order to get you in the door. I served on more than 7 faculty searches so this is based on experience. 

Less pressure to do research, but some departments still expect you to perform miracles and bring in 400k grants while teaching 4-4, advising 50 students, leading multiple clubs, and overseeing 5-10 student researchers a semester. Don't forget service expectations and networking with industry partners. If you are expecting an easy gig compared to an R1, you'll be in for a surprise.

Low cost of living. Small town, mostly safe.

Benefits are quite amazing. Great health insurance and retirement (actually funded, unlike other states *cough, cough* Illinois).
cons:
See comment above about toxic departments. My department had had ongoing battles for years. All petty. One other department had multiple lawsuits and scandals.

Expect long hours and a lot of work.

Small town mentality can be difficult to handle. There are some faculty from outside SW Wisconsin, but the vast majority are "lifers." UW-Platteville used to offer quite a few MS degrees and many faculty got there undergraduate and graduate degrees at UW-Platteville, went away for a short PhD, and then came back. Some administrators have their positions because of connections and not merit. This has become much rarer under Chancellor Shields, but there are still quite a few holdovers.

Small town in the Midwest. Winters are long and there isn't too much to do if you are used to city life. If you are craving rural life and seeing everyone that you know all the time, then it could be great for you.

pros: Fits into your schedule.  Also, if you work as a research assistant, you can make more money and it looks good on your resume.  The teachers on campus are really intelligent and you can learn a lot by being a research assistant for one of them.
cons: Sometimes the management is a little too flexible, where it's easy to push off the work and focus on other things.  However, if you are able to manage your time good then I wouldn't say that this is a con at all.

review_title: Some great people on the ground, but rapid growth for growth sake deteriorates learning
pros: Some great educators who care about the students.  Good student programs.  Good benefits.
cons: Administration emphasis on growth has allowed many students into the university who are unprepared and in my opinion UW-P is setting them up for failure.  The pay is low.
